    Example Simulation Code

Data generation function for counter example

Source: R/datagen_counter.R
datagen.counter.Rd

This function generates the simulation data (exposure X, outcome Y, potential mediators M, and covariate V1) for counter example.

The number of potential mediators is set to be p = 19.

For each subject i = 1, ..., n:

  • \(X_i \stackrel{i.i.d}{\sim} N(0, 1)\)

  • \({V_1}_i \stackrel{i.i.d}{\sim} N(0, 1)\)

  • \(cov(X, V_1) = 0.8\)

  • \(M_{i,k} = \alpha_k X_i + {V_1}_i {\eta_1}_k + e_{1_{i,k}}\), where \(e_{1_{i,k}} \stackrel{i.i.d}{\sim} N(0, 1), k = 1, ..., p\), and \(cov(e_{1_{i,k}},e_{1_{i,j}} = 0)\) for k not equal j

  • \(Y_i = X_i + \sum_k \beta_{k} M_{i,k} + e_{2_{i}}\), where \(e_{2_{i}} \stackrel{i.i.d}{\sim} N(0, 1)\)

We let \(\alpha_1, \cdots, \alpha_{10}\) be randomly from the uniform distribution from -1 to 1 and \(\alpha_{11}, \cdots, \alpha_{19}\) be 0.

We let \({\eta_1}_{11} = 1\) and the rest of the \(\eta_1\) values be 0.

We let \(\beta_1, \cdots, \beta{9} = 0\) and \(\beta_{10}, \cdots, \beta{19}\) be either 1 or -1, randomly.

M10 is the true mediators (i.e., having non-zero alpha and beta coefficients).

Usage

datagen.counter(n)

Arguments

n

sample size

Value

The resulting data has 4 lists: X, Y, M, V1

Examples

set.seed(23)
data = datagen.counter(n = 1000)
head(data$X)
#>             [,1]
#> [1,] -0.02158138
#> [2,]  1.61887846
#> [3,]  1.38667551
#> [4,]  0.20707462
#> [5,]  0.74535031
#> [6,] -0.27278171
head(data$Y)
#>            [,1]
#> [1,]  1.0435139
#> [2,] -0.2097866
#> [3,]  1.9088426
#> [4,]  4.1112320
#> [5,]  0.4821536
#> [6,]  3.3867542
head(data$M)
